content.title: Knowledge Bowl Physics Module
content.description: Comprehensive physics preparation for Knowledge Bowl competition

learningObjectives.statement: Recall and apply Newton's three laws of motion
Calculate work, energy, and power in mechanical systems
Identify key physicists and their contributions
Explain wave phenomena including interference and diffraction

segments.content: Welcome to Knowledge Bowl Physics preparation. This module covers the essential physics concepts you'll encounter in competition, from classical mechanics to modern physics.

children.title: Classical Mechanics
children.description: Newton's laws, motion, forces, energy, and momentum

segments.content: Classical mechanics forms the foundation of physics competition questions. Master Newton's laws and energy concepts.

children.title: Newton's Laws of Motion
children.description: The three fundamental laws governing motion and forces

segments.content: Newton's three laws describe how objects move. The First Law (inertia) states objects maintain their state unless acted upon. The Second Law relates force, mass, and acceleration (F=ma). The Third Law describes action-reaction pairs.
Let's cover Newton's three laws, which are among the most commonly tested physics concepts in Knowledge Bowl.

glossaryTerms.definition: The tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion
glossaryTerms.spokenDefinition: Inertia is an object's resistance to changes in motion

glossaryTerms.definition: The vector sum of all forces acting on an object
glossaryTerms.spokenDefinition: Net force is the total of all forces combined

retrievalPrompts: What is Newton's First Law also called?
What equation represents Newton's Second Law?
If you push a wall, what does Newton's Third Law say happens?

assessments.title: Newton's First Law
assessments.prompt: This law of motion, sometimes called the law of inertia, states that an object at rest will stay at rest unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

correct.text: Correct! Newton's First Law is also known as the Law of Inertia.

incorrect.text: The Law of Inertia is Newton's First Law, describing objects' tendency to maintain their state of motion.

assessments.title: Newton's Second Law
assessments.prompt: According to this law, force equals mass times acceleration, expressed as F equals m a.

correct.text: Correct! F=ma is Newton's Second Law of Motion.

incorrect.text: F=ma is the mathematical expression of Newton's Second Law.

misconceptions.misconception: Heavier objects fall faster than lighter objects
misconceptions.correction: In a vacuum, all objects fall at the same rate regardless of mass. Air resistance affects falling speed in real-world conditions.

misconceptions.misconception: Mass and weight are the same thing
misconceptions.correction: Mass is the amount of matter (kg), while weight is the gravitational force on that mass (N). Weight = mass times gravity.

children.title: Energy and Work
children.description: Kinetic energy, potential energy, work-energy theorem, and conservation of energy

segments.content: Energy exists in many forms. Kinetic energy (KE = 1/2 mv squared) is energy of motion. Potential energy is stored energy. The work-energy theorem states that work equals change in kinetic energy. Energy is conserved in isolated systems.
Energy concepts appear frequently in competition. Know the formulas for kinetic and potential energy.

glossaryTerms.definition: Energy of motion, calculated as KE = (1/2)mv squared
glossaryTerms.spokenDefinition: Kinetic energy equals one-half times mass times velocity squared

glossaryTerms.definition: Stored energy due to position or configuration
glossaryTerms.spokenDefinition: Potential energy is energy stored due to an object's position

glossaryTerms.definition: Transfer of energy when a force moves an object, W = Fd cos(theta)
glossaryTerms.spokenDefinition: Work equals force times displacement times the cosine of the angle between them

assessments.title: Kinetic Energy
assessments.prompt: This type of energy, calculated as one-half times mass times velocity squared, describes the energy an object has due to its motion.

correct.text: Correct! Kinetic energy = (1/2)mv squared is the energy of motion.

incorrect.text: KE = (1/2)mv squared is the formula for kinetic energy, the energy of motion.

children.title: Waves and Optics
children.description: Wave properties, sound, light, and electromagnetic spectrum

segments.content: Wave physics covers properties of mechanical and electromagnetic waves, including sound and light.

children.title: Wave Properties
children.description: Wavelength, frequency, amplitude, and wave speed

segments.content: Waves transfer energy without transferring matter. Key properties include wavelength (lambda), frequency (f), amplitude, and wave speed (v = f times lambda). Waves can be transverse or longitudinal.

assessments.title: Transverse Waves
assessments.prompt: This type of wave has oscillations perpendicular to the direction of energy transfer. Light and water waves are examples.

correct.text: Correct! Transverse waves oscillate perpendicular to energy transfer.

incorrect.text: Transverse waves have perpendicular oscillations. Light is a transverse wave.

children.title: Electromagnetic Spectrum
children.description: Radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, UV, X-rays, gamma rays

segments.content: The electromagnetic spectrum spans from low-frequency radio waves to high-frequency gamma rays. In order of increasing frequency: radio, microwave, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, X-ray, gamma. All EM waves travel at the speed of light in a vacuum.

children.title: Famous Physicists
children.description: Key scientists and their contributions to physics

segments.content: Knowledge Bowl frequently asks about famous physicists. Know their key discoveries and contributions.

children.title: Modern Physicists
children.description: Einstein, Bohr, Heisenberg, Feynman, Hawking, and others

segments.content: Key modern physicists include Albert Einstein (relativity, photoelectric effect), Niels Bohr (atomic model), Werner Heisenberg (uncertainty principle), Richard Feynman (QED), and Stephen Hawking (black holes, cosmology).
